titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.50 Richmond, Va. Friday, February 27, 1863 price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div4.p: --The Senate met at 12 o'clock, and was called to order by Mr. Hunter, of Virginia, and opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Moore, of the Presbyterian Church.
The further consideration of the bill to organize the Supreme Court of the Confederate States was postponed until the 27th instant, on motion of Mr. Clark of Mo.
House bill to authorize and regulate impressments of private property for the use of the army and other military purposes was read.
Mr. Haynas, of Tenn., moved to substitute the Senate impressment bill for the House bill.
To this amendment Mr. Hunter, of Va., moved an amendment, to strike out the 31 section and insert an amendment which he offered, and which.
On motion of Mr. Yancey, was ordered to be printed.
On motion of Mr. Yancey, the further consideration of the subject was postponed until to- morrow.
On motion of Mr. Semmes, of La., the Senate resolved itself into secret session.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clk, and was called to order by the Speaker.

The Speaker laid before the House a communication from the President, transmitting a response from the Postmaster General to House resolution in relation to the management of telegraph lines within the Confederacy.
Referred to Committee on Post-Offices and Post Roads.

The Speaker also presented Senate bill to increase the pay of Acting Midshipmen in the Navy.
Referred to the Naval Committee.

Mr. H. W. Bruce, of Ky., moved to suspend the rules, with a view to take up for immediate consideration the bill providing for the trans or of soldiers, which had passed the House, but upon which there was a motion to reconsider.
On the motion to suspend the rules the ayes and noes were called and resulted — ayes 58, noes 19.
So the rules were suspended and the bill was taken up.

The question recurred upon the motion of Mr. Ralls, of Ala., to reconsider the vote by which the bill was passed by the House.
The resolution was rejected by a vote of ayes 35, noes 41.

Mr. Miles, of S. C., moved that the Senate bill defining who shall be exempt from military service in the armies of the Confederate States be printed, which was agreed to, and the bill was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.

Mr. R. W. Bruce, of Ky., called up the resolution submitted by him several days ago to rescind the rule limiting speeches to thirty minutes on any one question and addressed the House briefly in support of the resolution.
The question being called and sustained on the adoption of the resolution.

Mr. Jones, of Tenn., called the ayes and noes, which were ordered, and resulted — ayes 36, noes 48.
So the resolution was not agreed to.

Mr. Miles, of S. C., from the Committee on Military Affairs reported back the two joint resolutions referred to that committee tendering the thanks of Congress to Gen. Braxton Bragg, and the officers and men of his command, for gallant services in front of Murfreesboro', and moved that these resolutions be laid on the table, with a view to submit a substitute from the committee.
The substitute of the committee was reported by the Clerk.

Mr. Foote, of Tenn., said that when this subject was introduced in the House, a few days ago he announced that he should perhaps have something to say upon it when it came up for consideration.
He proceeded to speak of the position he had occupied, but he was gratified to say that he had received such information as would lead him to support the resolutions.
He then read the following from General Joseph E. Johnston:

div5.head:
Headq'rs Chattanooga,
Jan. 28, 1863.
div5.p:
Gen. Johnston has great satisfaction in expressing to this command his sense of the high services and admirable conduct of the Army of Tennessee, especially in the recent operations near Murfreesboro'. In those operations that patriotic army, contending with greatly superior numbers, by its own condone, and the skill of its General inflicted upon the enemy a loss almost equal to its own number, besides capturing thirty-three cannon and a thousand wagons — an exploit unparalleled in modern battles.
For its heroic fortitude in enduring fatigue, privation, and exposure, and bravery in battle, he can, with confidence, promise to it the thanks of the Government and gratitude of the country.
div5.closer:
By command of Gen. Johnston.
B. S. Ewell A. A. G.

div5.p: The question then recurred upon the engrossment of the resolutions, and the ayes and noes being ordered, were taken with the following result — ayes 78, noes 2--Messrs Lyons of Va., and Read of Ky. The resolutions were then agreed to
On motion of Mr. Kanner, of La., the House then went into secret session on the currency bill.

div4.p:
--The Senate met at 12 M., the Lieut. Governor in the chair.
Prayer by Rev. Dr. Moore.

A message was received from the House asking concurrence in Senate act establishing a tobacco Inspection agency in Keene's warehouse, in the town of Danville, passed by the House of Delegates.
Also, the act amending the act to further provide for the public defence.
Referred to committees.

A communication from the Executive enclosed one from the Superintendent of the Penitentiary, calling the attention of the General Assembly to the necessity of an increase of the guard stationed there, with a commensurate increase of pay. Referred to the Committee on the Penitentiary.

Committee Bills Reported.--A bill amending the Code of Virginia, so as to increase the pay of members and officers of the General Assembly.
A bill making an appropriation for the Central Lunatic Asylum.
Reported back from the committee without amendment.

Resolutions.--By Mr. Carson: Inquiring into the expediency of paying persons who were employed as drill masters in the militia when called into service.
Agreed to.

Mr. Robertson introduced a series of joint resolutions in relation to the privileges of the Senate, with the view of heading off the bill introduce to provide representation from sections in possession of the enemy.
After much discussion, the resolutions were referred to the Committee for Courts of Justice.
The discussion of the bill authorizing fiduciaries to invest funds in Confederate bonds consumed the time up to the hour of adjournment.
On motion, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 11 o'clock. Prayer by the Rev. Dr. Duncan.

Mr. Rutherfoord, from the Committee on Courts reported back, with recommendation that it pass, the bill increasing the allowance for board and lodging of jurors in criminal cases; also, the bill allowing John Parsons, Sheriff of Lee county, further time to qualify and give bond of office, and recommend its passage; also, bill forfeiting lands of citizens of the United States in this State, when said lands are claimed by loyal citizens under grants from the Commonwealth, to transfer the same.

Mr. Prince offered a resolution, which was agreed to, authorizing the Committee on Military Affairs to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill providing for the transfer to the Confederate authorities of all prisoners captured by the State Line under Maj-Gen. J. B. Floyd.
Mr. McCamant, from the Committee on Propositions and Grievances, to whom had been referred the bill incorporating the Farmville Insurance Company, reported the same back without amendment.
On motion of Mr. Hunter, Senate bill to transfer the State Line to the Confederate Government was taken up and considered.

Pending an amendment offered by Mr. Richardson, the hour for the consideration of the order of the day — the Tax bill — arrived, and that subject was resumed, and its consideration continued up to the hour of adjournment.

div3.head: A solemn warning to wives.
div3.p:
--A correspondent of the Selma Reporter relates a story which should serve as a solemn warning to the wives of soldiers.
He says a few weeks ago a soldier was tried and convicted of the crime of desertion, and sentenced to be shot.
The day for the execution arrived, and at the appointed hour this brave man, who had fought many battles and endured every kind of hardship, fell a bloody corpse at the hands of his comrades.
Upon inquiry it was ascertained he was as true as steel to our cause, and that it was on account of his wife that he deserted.
He received a letter from her full of complaints.
Looking alone upon the dark side of the picture, she had magnified her troubles and sufferings, and earnestly entreated her husband to return home.
He became restless, discontented, unhappy.
He ceased to make any interest in the discharge of his military duties, and thought only of how he could get home.
His solemn oath never to desert troubled him much, and he well knew the crime of desertion had become so frequent in the army it would be punished with death.
In this state of perplexity he drew his wife's letter from his bosom and read it again, and, shutting his eyes to the consequences, in deserted? and for this crime he suffered a bloody and ignominious death.
His wife, now a widow, known no peace of mind, but is constantly haunted with the thought that her exaggerated representations of her trials and sufferings caused her husband's death.
Let this case be a lesson to all wives and mothers.
When you write to the soldier speak words of encouragement; cheer their hearts; fire their souls, and arouse their patriotism.
Say nothing that will embitter their thoughts, or swerve them from the path of patriotic duty.

div4.head: The U. S. National currency.
div4.p:
This bill has passed both Houses of the Yankee Congress.
Mr. Baker, of the House, in discussing it, said:

q.p:
This bill will introduce an inconvertible and irredeemable currency.
Shams upon its authors.--By it our banking system will be totally annihilated and driven out by taxation.
It gives unlimited power to one man. It places in the hands of the Secretary the basis of the whole banking institution of the country.
A breath might make and a breath might unmake us all. Suppose this system of operation was in the hands of the comptroller, and suppose a rumor should go forth that there had been a defalcation, what would be its effect?
None can measure it. It is incalculable.
He was not willing to place the whole business and interests of our country at such hazards.
If this system had been inaugurated in Buchanan's Administration, what to-day would have been our condition?

div4.p: Mr. Noell said:

q.p: This bill gives the Government the power to go into all the States and Inaugurate a system of opening banks independent of each other, and having no national character.

div4.head: Vallandigham's birth and parentage and Extraction.
div4.p:
A Confederate paper has stated that Clement L. Vallandigham was not a Yankee, but of Maryland birth; but we take the annexed paragraph from a speech of Mr. Vallandigham, delivered in the Lincoln House of Representatives and published in the Congressional Globe, of the 15th of January. It the fact that Mr. Vallandigham is a native of Ohio, but of Southern parentage.
He says:

q.p:
And now, sir, I, who have not a drop of New England blood in my veins but was born in Ohio, and am wholly of Southern ancestry, with a slight cross of Pennsylvania Scotch Irish, would speak a word to the West and the South, in behalf of New England.
Sir, some years ago, in the midst of high sectional controversies, and speaking as a Western man I said some harsh of the North, which new, in a more catholic spirit, as a United States man, and for the each of reunion.
I would recall My prejudless indeed, upon this subject are as strong as any man's; but in this, the day of great national humiliation and calamity, 1st the voice of prejudice be hushed.

div4.head: Pen and ink Sketchis of some of our Generals.
div4.p: A correspondent of the Mobile Advertiser given the annexed pen and ink sketches of some of our Generals in the West:

div4.head: Gen. Van-Dorn.
div4.p:
In height Earl Var-Dorn is five feet six or eight inches, and compact but not stout in stature.
His hair is long and curly, and of a dark chestnut color, as are his moustache and imperial, which are large and thick.
His features are somewhat bronzed by exposures, but are peculiarly pleasant and agreeable.
His eye is large, and a beautiful clear blue.--His speech is ready and voluminous, yet chaste.--He has extremely fascinating address and manners, and is open, free and frank.
You will take great pleasure in conversing with him, and feel perfectly at case.
He is always accessible, and treats every one with courtesy.
With the ladies he is an especial favorite and the fascination of his address exercises a great influence over the tender sex, towards whom he is always affable, courteous, and gallant.
He has no special peculiarity of manners other then always appearing at his ease, and frequently moving his hand through his luxuriant curly hair.
He is upwards of 40 years of age, though his appearance would not indicate that he is a year above 30 Gen. Van-Dorn is decidedly a handsome and fascinating gentleman.
To his friends he is warm, open, and generous to a fault.
To his enemies, charitable and lenient.

div4.head: Gen. Armstrong.
div4.p:
Gen. Armstrong is six feet in height, well proportioned graceful in figure, port erect, and unusually handsome.
His features are regular, his mouth perfect, and his eyes are black, brilliant, and expressive.
His hair is black, and he sports a handsome black moustache, while his eyes gleam out from beneath a pair of fine black eyebrows.--He has a nonchalant manner, is always at his ease, and is regarded by gentlemen as very handsome, and considered by the ladies a beau ideal.
To look at him it strikes the observer at once that he is an ornament for the prior, and the soldiers know that he is as useful as he is ornamental.
His age is about thirty.

div4.head: Gen. Jackson.
div4.p:
W. H. Jackson is a well proportioned man, about five feet ten inches in height.
He --The color of his hair, dark auburn.
His features are prepossessing and expressive.
He is courteous and gentlemanly, and easily approached.
He has a youthful appearance, and is about thirty-two years old. He has had command of a brigade of cavalry for the past eight months, if not longer, and has been constantly on outpost duty.

div4.head: Changes in political terms.
div4.p: In the volume of transactions of the British Philological Society, just published, is a pacer by Mr. Lother Bucher, on political terms, in which the author gives some curious instances of the times at which particular words and phrases have come into use and the manner in which their meaning has changed; thus be quotes a special of Sir Robert Walpole in 1742, as containing the first mention he can find of the term "prime minister."

In England, that which we call the administration is spoken of as the government — or more commonly, is simply government, without the article.
Englishmen speak of Lord Palmerston's government.
Lord Derhy's government, just as we speak of Mr. Lincoln's or Mr. Buchanan'a administration.
This term is, however, quite recent.--Not many years ago the phrase was the ministers or the ministry, and in Cathara's time the commonest word was that we use, the administration, or more usually without the article administration.

During the revolutionary war and we believe for some time afterward, Congress was always spoken of in the plural, as Congress have, and in the earlier years of the war it was usual to say the Congress.
On the use of the term public opinion Mr. Bucher gives several curious particulars:

My earliest certificates of existence of the compound public opinion are in French the New Holoine, 1759.
In English the dispatch of Lord Stormont of January 20, 1781. In Furguson's history of the Roman Empire, 1783 it occurs three times; in his essays on civil society, 1767, the same idea is fully treated of, but expressed otherwise.
In the first five instances embracing the time from 178 to 1796, the definite article is invariably added the public opinion.
This addition would be very unusual now-a-days; I doubt whether any living writer would put it so. In consulting various grammars I have not found any satisfactory explanation of this phenomenon in the growth of language.
My impression is, in this individual case, that the loss of the article corresponds with the rise of the word from the dry term of the historian, and the half-sneering expression of the diplomatist to the name of a personified power, a human. And if that be the case we may, in the further loss recently to be observed, of the adjective public in the use of the simple word opinion, trace its further flight to a perfect deity or a perfect nothing.
He gives an instance of the abuse of a term which has its parallel on our side of the water at this day.

One may safely affirm beforehand that the word aristocracy has been part and parcel of the English language from a very early period.
But the Attorney General in Horne Tooke's trial (1795,) in enumerating the new opinion propagated by the friends of the accused and the accused and the new terms in which they conveyed these opinions, says: To the rich was given the name aristocracy; and in considering this application of the term as a new one he is evidently quite correct.

In like manner many American journals use the term Democracy when they mean to speak only of the so-called Democratic party as the Democracy of this State.
Democracy, like aristocracy, is the same of a particular form of Government; and it is a mischievous abuse of language to apply it to a party, because it breeds a confusion of ideas by which unthinking men are too apt to grant to the party, wrongly calling itself Democratic, the tributes and principles of a democracy.
As the Democratic party is at present, there is a very wide difference between theirs and the democratic principles.
By a singular fate, the Democratic party in this country is to-day the only upholders of that aristocratic and anti-democratic element in our republic which is striving to tear it to places.--New York Post.

div4.head: The women and the private soldiers.
div4.p: The following is an extract from a private letter written by an officer, now in the army, to his wife:

You are the most incorrigible patriot I know.
Hang me, if I don't believe you would sacrifice me for the cause. "These women." as old Stein used to say, "are the devil, " but if they were entitled to that distinction in times of peace, they are certainly the incarnate deities of a revolutionary war. I do not say this in disparagement of the sex; for I really believe that if we ever achieve our independence the glory of it should belong to the women and the private soldiers of the South.
The great work will be due to the ungrudging spirit of devotion and sacrifice animating women, and stimulating and supporting the tireless energy and heroic endurance of the soldiers.
Take my word for it the people who stay at home have no preception whatever of the splendid metal The tense it sends out when struck by the wild hand of war will ring through all history in a purer and grander key than was ever realized in the olden ages of chivalry.
The mailed warriors of ancient romance were sickly children of sentiment compared to the stern manhood and unconquerable grit of Southern soil.

For my part, there are but two classes engaged in this war who command my respect and admiration --woman and the private soldier.
I love, cherish, and obey the first as becomes a Christian gentleman; and I honor and reverence the last as the only living impersonation of a pure and unselfish patriotism.
May God protect their lives, and give to their country that peace and independence for which they are so nobly struggling.

div4.head: Southern women.
div4.p:
On the occasion of the recent departure of women for the South, from Washington, some remarkable developments took place.
A Yankee correspondent says:

q.p: One lady had seven pairs of gaiters, five pairs of boots, five pairs of morocco slippers, three pairs of dancing slippers of white kid, four pairs of India rubber overshoes, and a pair of the longest-legged cavalry boots, with double soles, studded with good spikes, heels tapped with shoes of iron, and tops splendidly ornamented with an abundance of patch work of waxed ends on a groundwork of patent leather.

div4.p:
"How about these, Madame?" said the officer, as he quietly insinuated the cavalry boots into her astonished gaze; "if you will put them on and wear them on your trip to Richmond, you can take them; but they can go with you under no other circumstances." "Done — I'll do it," said the heroine, and grasping the heavy leather in her hands, she retired behind the friendly crinoline of a group of sympathizers, and planting her pretty feet — gaiters and all — into the depths of that monstrous foot harness, returned, and awkwardly displayed them, double cased, to the gaping eyes of the this time astonished official.
He kept his word.
Those boots went to somebody in the Confederate army; or, they may have been an intended Christmas present for Gen. Stuart.
Those secede women do such things.

div3.head: Highly Important from Kentucky.
div3.p: --The Winchester (ocean,) Bulletin, of the 29th, has been informed by one of our Confederate Judges, who has just arrived from McMinnville, that news has reached that place from Kentucky, which he considers reliable, that the Legislature of that State passed resolutions on the 12th inst., calling on their Governor to issue a proclamation calling all the Kentucky troops in the Federal army home at once, to assist in preventing Lincoln from carrying out his emancipation or claimation.

div3.head: Recent robberies.
div3.p:
--The store of Captain James Charres, next adjoining the establishment of the late august Sehad on Broad street, was entered by robbers on Wednesday night and relieved of a lot of liquor and cigars and five hundred dollars in money.
Up to yesterday no clue had been obtained as to the robbers.

The store of Philip Spetin, corner of Main street and Locust alley, was broken into by thieves one night last week, who removed and sequestered to their own use a lot of boots and shoes.
They also broke open a desk and stole $900 in N. Carolina funds.
Getting a clue on the operators in this case, Messrs Maccubbin, Clacknor, and Goodrick, of the defective corps, arrested two men giving the names of P. W. Reynolds and David M. Preston as being concerned in the affair.

Preston lives at the corner of 20th and Main sts., and some of the stolen goods were found on his premised.
The arrest of the two men was accomplished on Wednesday last.
After being taken in custody they were put in Castle Lightning, and means were adopted to discover the extent of their complicity in the affair.
Preston admitted to the officers that he got into the house of Epstein and took the articles out, a portion of widen were found in his possession.
On yesterday the case having been worked up to such an extent as to insure the conviction of the guilty parties, they were carried from the military prison and delivered into the custody of the Mayor to be dealt with by the civil authorities.

In the matter of the robbery of Chiles & Chenery's store Mrs. Mary Connors, her daughter, and Frances Hueston who live on 11th, near the corner of Canal st, were arrested by Messrs Maccubbin, Custis, Franklin, and Williams, of Maj. Griswold's office, who found at the house occupied by the parties several hundred dollars' worth of Chiles & Chenery's goods, Mr. Chenery being with them, and identifying his property.
Joseph Bueston, a brother of one of the girls was arrested at Mrs. Connors's, ostensibly as a deserter, but really because he was believed to be one of the parties concerned in the robbery.
Such afterwards proved to be the case.
Being put in Castle Lightning, he and other desperadoes effected their escape.
The revelations made by Mrs. Connors, and the two girls arrested with her, led to the detection and recovery of a large lot of the stolen property and may eventually prove the means by which all of it can be restored to its owners.
The armed guard and city night watch do all they can to prevent robberies, but it in almost an impossibility, owing to the presence in our midst of such a number of place of refuge.

div3.head: Selling soldiers' discharges.
div3.p:
--The detectives of Major Griswold's office yesterday a rested and put in Castle Thunder a man named John Stephens, belonging to company I, 1st Georgia regiment, on the charge of selling house discharges to soldiers belonging to the Confederate army.
He had on his person when arrested twenty eight blank discharges, ready for signature, and a considerable sum which he had accumulated by the sale of the article.
Any soldier who could furnish five dollars could get a discharge.
The frequency of perfectly hearty and sound men being discharged from the army led to an inquiry, which disclosed the whole affair and ended in the arrest of Stephens, who will be tried before Court Martial for his offence.

--Judge Wm. H. Lyons presiding.--John Ginotti, indicted for burglary, in breaking into the store-house of Antoine Mazzini, with intent to commit a larceny, was tried for burglary, and acquitted.
Afterwards defendant was taken into custody and remanded to jail, to be re-indicted for an offence growing out of the above affair.

Patrick Cunningham Julius Desplauques Jas. Kelley, Wm. Harman, and Thos. Tyrer, were tried for garroting Isaac Jacobs, in the city jail, and robbing him of several hundred dollars and a watch.
The proof was positive, and the jury, after hearing the evidence, found all the parties guilty, and ascertained the term of each at four years in the State prison.
A jury was sworn in the case of Wm. R. Warden, for obtaining lard from John Q. Taylor by false pretences and the trial was proceeding yesterday evening.

On Wednesday.
Thomas Turpin a lad tried for robbing David Smith of $35, was acquitted by the jury sworn in the case.
--The case of Sidney, slave of Albert Graham, charged with stealing $1,200 from Robert McClellan, was partly heard, and continued for additional evidence.

Caroline Isaacs and Myer Myers were arraigned for receiving a large lot of dry goods, stolen from the store of Chiles & Chenery, knowing the same to have been stolen.
Several witnesses were sworn and testified, and the case adjourned to Saturday for further developments.

James Powers, arrested for beating Baptist Dennis contrary to law was arraigned and the proof sustaining the allegation defendant, in default of bail, was sent to prison to await an indictment by the Grand Jury of the Hustings Court.
Robert Stewart, who represented himself as a worker of Government shoes, was committed to jail in default of bail for getting drunk, behaving disorderly in the Theatre and the police.
Three soldiers, charged with a nearly similar offence, were sent before the Provost Marshal.

div3.head: The liquor board.
div3.p:
--The board appointed by Gen. Winder consisting of Major Griswold and Capts. Alexander, Maynard, and Booker, for the adjudication of claims for liquor seized under martial law, meets daily at the office of the Gas.
Inspector, City Hall, at 12 o'clock M. Parties who have filed their claims for liquor seized are appearing daily and filing the evidence to support their claims.
The board from the amount of business before it, will no doubt be forced to continue its sessions for some time longer.
The liquor, when a claim is allowed, is paid for either in kind or in money, at the option of the Government.

div3.head: Official privileges.
div3.p:
--Any commissioned officer of the Confederate States Army can get, on application to the Quartermasters, from the Government stores sugar, molasses, bacon, and similar articles, at Government prices, and this, for sugar is three cents per pound, and for molasses, twenty cents per gallon.
This is a privilege denied the privates, as we learn.
No commissioned officer ever gets less than $80 per month and rations, while the majority get a far greater sum — some receiving several hundred dollars per month as pay. The pay of a private soldier is $11 per month, and sugar sells in this market, lowing to the want of transportation, the latter being absorbed by the Government,) at $1 per pound, and molasses at $10 per gallon.
Judging from the amount of pay received by the soldier, and the cost of such articles of consumption as are enumerated above, it would seem that the private soldier had very little show to indulge in such luxuries as sugar and molasses.

div3.head: The city.
div3.p:
--The extreme inclemency of the weather for more than a week past has operated to deter many country people from bringing their accustomed supplies to this market.
The latter may now be said to present a beggarly account of empty benches.
The supply of vegetables, poultry, fish, and butchers' meat, have all been cut short by the difficulty experienced in making headway against the acres of mud and slush encountered in the attempt to get to Richmond.
The prices now asked and obtained for all articles for the table are beyond all precedent, and growing daily with a supply.
For several mornings past a number of the prominent butchers have been compelled to close their stalls because they could get no beef to sell.
Those who have kept open cannot felicitate themselves on the quality of the meat they expose for sale.
A brisk rain yesterday nearly cleared away the snow, but several weeks must elapse before the roads leading to this city can be considered in good condition.

argument.p: capture of the Yankee gunboat Indianola" by the Queen of the West."

div4.p: The following official dispatches were received in this city yesterday:

Vicksburg Feb. 25.--To Gen. S. Cooper.:--I have the honor to report, after a severe and hot engagement, the capture of the Federal iron clad steamer Indianola, Lieut.-Commanding Brown, U. S. N., together with all her officers and crew, by the Confederate States steamers Queen of the West and Webb, forming an expedition sent out by me for that purpose, under the command of Major Brent.
The prize is a good deal damaged.

--To Gen. S. Cooper:--The expedition fitted up at Red river and Fort Hudson captured the iron-clad gunboat Indianola at 11 P. M. last night.
She is now sunk on the Mississippi shore, bow and upper works out, near Mr. Joe Davis's plantation.
Her armament consists of two 11 inch guns forward, and two 9 inch aft.--Lieut. Brown, U. S. N., commanding with his officers and men, were captured.
We will do everything possible to raise and get her offset immediately.
There will probably be an attempt for her Iron-Clads to run down past our batteries to night. --Major J. L. Brent, of Gen. Taylor's forces, commanded the expedition.
--The Advertiser and Register has the following:

Jackson Feb. 25.--I am permitted to copy the following dispatch to Gen. Pemberton, dated Port Gibson, 25th: Last night about 10 o'clock, with the steamer Dr. Baly, four miles below Vicksburg, I fell in with the United States iron-clad gunboat Indianola.
After the ram Queen of the West and the Webb had engaged her for an hour, I went alongside, when her Commander, Lieut. Brown, U. S. N., surrendered to me. As all credit is due Major Brent, I have turned over to him, in a sinking condition, the prize, which we hope to save.--Nobody but five hurt.

div3.head: From the South Carolina Coast.
div3.p:
--Our latest advices from Port Royal state that the Yankee fleet, now there, numbers 123 vessels, including three frigates and twenty gunboats.
The rest are chiefly transports.
There are now 30,000 men collected there, and more expected.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of Valuable Real and Personal property at auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at public auction, Tuesday, the 10th of March next, on the promises, the Farm of Povall Turner dec'd., (known as Pitts's,) on the Chickahominy river, in the county of New Kent. three miles from Summit depot, on the York River Railroad and twenty miles from Richmond, containing 693 acres, of which about 400 are in a high state of cultivation, well enclosed, and adapted to the growth of corn, wheat, and oats, with 125 bushels of winter oats and 24 bushels of wheat seeded, and a portion mailed and act in clover, with a dwelling-house and all other necessary out houses, and a well of excellent water in the yard.
The balance of the land is in original growth of pine, oak, maple, and cypress.
Also, the Farming Utensils, stock of valuable Mules, Horse, Oxen.
Cows, Sheep, and Hogs.
Also, Buggies, Carriages, Carts, Wagons, Corn, Oats, Fodder, Hay, Shucks, and Straw; Household and Kitchen Furniture, Bacon Lard, and Poultry.

Also, at the same time and place, a Tract of Land, detached from and within a quarter of a mile of the farm, containing 80 acres, well enclosed with a plank fence, one-half in cultivation, with valuable low grounds, and well adapted for a pasturage.
Also, 50 acres lying on the York River Railroad, fifteen miles from Richmond, which has on it a dwelling-house, and some wood and timber standing on it.
Also, a first-class Steam Saw Mill and fixtures, of twenty four horse power, in good repair.
Terms.--For the real estate, made known on the day of sale; cash will be required for the perishable property.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of 86 acres of Land, in Henrico county, on the Deep-run Turnpike, at auction.
div3.p:
--As Administrator of John Ford dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Monday, 2d day of March, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep-Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs E. J. A. Smith. John W. Alley, and James Shephard.
It contains 86 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms; Barn, Stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico co. and as such
Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas. H. Ford who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 17

div3.head: Beautiful improved Farm, near Charlottesville, and Twelve or fifteen Negroes, for Sale.
div3.p:
--In obedience to a decree of the Circuit Court of Albemaria, pronounced in the chancery suit of "Henderson and wife vz Crawford and sts.," the undersigned Commissioners will offer for sale, at public auction, on the promises, on Tuesday, the 3d day of March, 1863, (or the next fair day,) a beautiful aucts, known as Meadow Creek, containing about 600 acres. This farm lies within a mile of Charlottesville, and less than a mile from the University of Virginia; has an abundance of timber; is smooth and gently undulating, susceptible of a high degree of improvement; has a large creek passing entirely through the place, affording a quantity of fine meadow land, well act in old grass yielding a large quantity of hay; and there is a spring of running water in every field.
There is an excellent dwelling-house, and all the necessary out-houses, and a fine peach orchard on the place.
It is seldom that so desirable a place, in the immediate vicinity of a large town, is offered for sale.
Will be sold at the same time and place, 12 or 13 likely Negroes, Household and Kitchen Furniture, a fine Piano, two good Milch Cows, &c.
Terms.--Pretty much at the option of the purchaser.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 50, page 2.

div3.head: Remittances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company by which all money for subscription, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money to be sent should be enclosed in an envelope, directed to the "Richmond Dispatch. Richmond, Virginia," and scaled with wax, writing the subscriber's name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to any agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and follow them.

div3.head: Type Wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil, or Adate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: Lincoln's huge army.
div3.p:
The Yankee Congress hat, by one dash, made an absolute monarch of Lincoln.
It has given him the entire control of the purse and the sword.--those instruments of absolute power which it has ever been the unceasing policy of all Anglo Saxon peoples to keep separated.
The hand that grass both the purse and the sword is the hand of an absolute, irresponsible monarch, and written Constitutions and paper guarantees, laws and legislatures, are more toys in his sight.
For the sake of destroying the people of the South the Yankee Congress has tamely surrendered every barrier against Executive encroachment, every bulwark of liberty, every safeguard even of person or property.
Lincoln is undisputed master of everything.
It remains with him to say whether he will permit any more legislation, whether he will go out at the end of his term, whether another Congress shall ever assemble; or, if he should determine to permit it to assemble, whether it shall be anything more than a convenient machine for registering his edicts.
The Yankees have been living under a virtual despotism for two years.--The present system is not merely an actual despotism; it is such in name, as well as fact.

Every men between the ages of 18 and 45 is placed at the disposal of Lincoln for military service.
He had has power, not only to keep in the ranks the 300,000 who, it was fondly hoped, would go out in May that he may add thereto 3,000,000 if he see fit. The illusion with regard to the power of the Yankee Government to sustain the strain upon their finances is dissipated by a breath.
The Congress has annihilated the State banks at allow, and made "green backs" the only currency within Lincoln's dominions.
So Lincoln can have as many soldiers as he may wish, and pay them, too. Another illusion still exists.
It is supposed that those who are out of the field at present will refuse to go, and that those who are in it already will revolt in a body.
This is all folly.
If men at home refused to go, they will be compelled to do it at the point of the bayonet.
If men already in the field refuse to serve any longer, they, too, will be compelled, unless the whole body lay down their arms at one movement, or turn them against their officers.
This is a thing unheard of in war. Suppose these men all revolt, how are they to be fed?
How are they to get away?
Where is the money for their necessities to come from?
It is folly to make any such calculation.
There may be desertions on an enormous scale; but the bulk of the army will remain.

Let us, therefore, dismiss all the idle hopes which we may have been induced to entertain by the knowledge that a large body of the enemy's forces go out of service in May.
Those troops will stay voluntarily if they choose it, by force if they oppose it. So far from being diminished, the Yankee force is about to be prodigiously increased.
We must meet it, and we must beat it. That can be done only by pushing the conscription to its utmost limit, and thereby by preserving the proportion we have always borne to them.
There is no the slightest ground for discouragement in all this.
They have always been vastly superior to us in numbers and they have uniformly been beaten upon every field of importance.
Even now with the largest army that has taken the field since the time of Xerxes, they have shown themselves unable throughout the winter, the season most propitious to them from their enormous superiority on the water to make the slightest impression upon us if with 850,000 men they had themselves incompetent to make the least advance, what can they effect by doubting or trebling their numbers?
It is not men that they want.
They have a numerical force sufficient to conquer the world.
It is the heart, the soul, the spirit that is wanting — that leaven which leavens the whole lump — that principle without which an army, be it as large as it may, is a more carcass — a body devoid of life, and fit only to be the sport of its enemies.--Three millions of men must necessarily be a mob. It is not in the power of man to reduce such a multitude to anything resembling the shape of a well trained army.
Such mobs never have made, and never will make, conquests.
It has been by much smaller bands of hardy, resolute, well disciplined men, that great leaders, in all ages, have effected the subjugation of nations.
Alexander invaded the East with 35,000 men. Caesar subdued Giant with four legions — about 25,000.
Bonaparte overran and conquered Italy with but 30,000.
But one man of modern times has lived who could handle 500,000 men. The Yankees have not one General that can handle the twentieth part of that number, and unless troops be well handled numbers are of no avail.

Let us, then, make up our minds to meet these huge mobs without any doubts as to the result. --They will but stand in the way of each other.
They will but render order and discipline — hard enough now to enforce in their armies — absolutely impossible.
Let it be remembered that we cannot and must not give up. To do so were to abandon everything, for these blood-thirsty wretches avow a determination to extinguish the inhabitants and to possess the land.
Our own opinion is that they will only make our victory the more glorious by the enormous numbers they bring to render it impossible.

div3.head: Maryland.
div3.p:
That the sympathies of Maryland, by which we mean the native Southern population of Maryland, and even of the District of Columbia, are thoroughly with the South we have seen no reason to doubt.
And the sympathies of the South are universally with Maryland.
Betrayed by domestic traitors and with the bayonets of a huge hireling army at their throats, she has had no alternative but submission.
Like Kentucky and those portions of the Southern Confederacy which have been overrun by the enemy, she has been compelled to keep quiet, but neither in one case or the other is this enforced submission any evidence of loyalty to the Washington despotism.
We should never permit the confidence of our people in each other to be interrupted by misfortunes like those which have shackled the limbs and scaled the utterances of Maryland, the majority of whose people are heart and soul with the South.

div3.head: Married.
div3.p: In Lynchburg, Va., on Monday the 16th inst. by the Rev. W. H. Kinckle, William M. Wellford, Jr. of Culpeper county to Annir N. daughter of Col. James M. Langhorne, of that city.

div4.p: on Wednesday, 25th inst, at 1½ o'clock, after an illness of eight months, Mrs. Mary Shekes, wife of John F. Shoter, in the 36th year of her age.
she leaves a devoted husband and three children to bemoan their irreparable less.

lg.l: a light is from our household gone;
a voice we loved is stilled;
a place is vacant at our hearth,
A gentle heart, that throbbed but now,
Has hushed its weary throbbing here

div4.p: Her funeral will take place from the residence of her husband, in Manchester, this afternoon at 3 o'clock. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend, without further notice. *
On the 25th inst. Miss Martha H. Braxton, daughter of Robert C. Braxton, Esq., of Henrico.
The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral this (27th) day, at 12 o'clock, from the First Baptist Church. *

at General Hospital, no. 1, in the city of Richmond, private William J. Ryals, a member of Company C, 14th Regiment Va. Vols, in the 22d year of his age, leaving a wife and numerous friends to mourn their loss.

lg.l: Dearest husband, thou hast left us;
Here thy loss we deeply feel;
But 'tis God who hath bereft us,
He can all our sorrows heal.

div4.p: The Religious Herald will please copy. *

On the 24th inst., in Manchester, in the 59th year of her age, Mrs. Naroissa M. Short, after a painful illness of two months, which she bore with becoming Christian patience and fortitude, indicating, from expressions in her dying moments, that our loss was her eternal gain.
div4.closer:
A. Son.
Columbia (S. C.) papers please copy. 2t*

div4.p: On 24th inst, at Clover Fields, Albemarle county, Mrs. Isabella Cleland, wife of Dr. John F. Gardner, of Nelson county, and daughter of the late F. K. Nelson, of Albemarle.
At Hallfax C. H. on the 14th inst., Mildred Clarkson, only child of William C. and C. T. Marshall, of Fauquier county, Va., aged 3 months and 20 days.
Of typhoid fever, at Mobile, Ala., on the 4th inst., while attached to the steamer Gaines, Midshipman W. W. Hunter C. S. N. son of Commander T. T. Hunter, C. S. N. *
On the 24th of February, at the house of John B. G. ayes, on Union Hill, Richmond, Va. Edwin C. B.
God giveth and God taketh away. *

div3.head:
Ordnance Dep't of Va.,
Richmond, Feb'y 20, 1863.
div3.p: Second Class Militia--Officers of the Second Class Militia to whom Arms have been issued for their companies by this Department, are hereby required to deliver the same to me at the Virginia Armory, corner of 7th and Cary sts., with as little delay as possible.
div3.closer:
By order:
P. G. Cogmlaw, Captain.
Ordnance Dep't of Va. fe 21--ts

div3.head: Two hundred and Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--For my woman Vina who escaped from the Bollingbrook Hotel, in Petersburg, the 12th of Jan'y. She had on a homespun dress.
She is about 25 years old, dark skin.
She was hired to Mr. Jno. Donnan, in Petersburg, in 1862.--I bought her from Mr. Alpheus A. Rowlett, in Chesterfield.
She may be harbored by some person in or near Petersburg.
If so, I will give $50 in addition to the above reward for their detection.
If caught, she may be placed in jail in Petersburg or Richmond.
Address any information concerning her to H. A. Pearce, Richmond Va., or Mr. Robt F. Jackson at the office of the South-Side railroad, Petersburg, Va.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, on or about the 25th of July, 1862 from the camp of the 7th Georgia my negro boy Isaac, frequently called Monk; aged 22 years 5 feet 5 inches high copper colored, large eyes, quick spoken quick galt.
When last heard from he was hiring himself as a free negro.
Any person who may arrest him and lodge him in any safe jail so that I can get him shall have the above reward.

div3.head: Ten dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway, on the 22d instant, from my residence, in Sidney, Henrico county, a negro boy named John, of a gingerbread color, about 11 years old. He had on a brown jacket and pantaloons.
I will give the above reward for his delivery to me.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $100 for the arrest and lodgment in a safe jail of my man George if taken out of the city of Richmond or county of Chesterfield, or $20 reward if taken in those limits.
He left my house, in Manchester, on the 14th inst., about 12½ o'clock P. M. He is about 6 feet high, 23 years old, brown color, and weighs about 190 pounds. He had on when he left a brown frock coat, and was well dressed generally.
He carried a bag of clothes with him. He came from near Danville, and is probably trying to get back.
He may hire himself to work in some camp or try to get off on the canal.
He had on a good black bat.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway from the subscriber, last spring, Albert, about 16 years of age, very black open countenance and lisps when speaking.
He is supposed to be employed by some officer in General Lee's army.
I will give the above reward for his arrest and return to me, or confinement in jail so that I can get him.
div3.closer:
Jno. O. Quaeles,
Corner Main and Foushee sts. fe 20--eod6t*

div3.head:
Freight officer & D. R. E,
Richmond, Feb. 10, 1863.
div3.p:
Special Notice.--Taken up at the depot of the Richmond and Danville Railroad, this day, a small negro boy, named John, who says he belongs to a Mr. Peter Burnley, from the country. --Said boy is about eight years old and of a gingerbread complexion.
The owner will come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take him away.

closer.signed: P. S. Ween R. & D. E. R.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--an Accountant, over 45, is prepared to Write up and balance Books.
He can give from five to six hours of his time (evening and night) to any one house requiring it. For information call on Maj. R. P. Waller who will receive any message on the subject.
Address "Mr. New"

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Immediately, Scared for a gentleman and his wife, (without children or servant,) in a location convenient to the business part of the city.
Address, stating terms. &c, "W. S. C." Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Teacher, to take charge of a small school in a pleasant neighborhood; one that is qualified to teach English French, and Music on Place.
None need apply who is not well recommended.
Address, as to salary, etc.
div3.closer:
Mrs. Sallish Tucker,
Riceville Pittsylvania Va. fe 27--d& w2t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Immediately, a first rate Adesman, who is accustomed to the Clothing Business and who can bring reliable recommendations.
For such an one I will pay a good salary, and give steady employment and a good situation.
Address "E," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A white or colored Woman, as Cook, Washer and Ironer, in a small family.
Good reference required.
Apply at Mrs. Gargle's Marshall st. 3d door from Monroe.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To rent, by the month, on Shockoe Hill, convenient to business, a Room, unfurnished, suitable for a chamber, and one as kitchen or to have the use of kitchen.
Address "Room. " Box No. 552, Post-Office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
-- for a lady, three children, and servant, in the country.
A place near one of the railroads preferred.
Address "W. A. W." Box 727, Richmond Post- Office stating terms, location

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Fifty men, for the Provost Marshal's Guard at Lynchburg.
Bounty, $50. For particular apply to
div3.closer:
H. M. Snovell,
Corner of 14th and Main sts. fe 27--1t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To buy a new or second-hand Buggy and Harness.
Also Sulkey and Harness.
div3.closer:
Hill & Noreleet,
Corner Va. and Cary streets. fe 27--2t

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Three negro men, to work in a Match Factory.
Apply to
div3.closer:
G. B. Thomson & Co.
Manchester Match Factory. fe 27--1t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A Gardener.--I wish to hire for the balance of the year a good Gardener.
div3.closer:
Thos Johnston, of West & Johnston,
145 Main street. fe 27--2t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Five or six good Beas Finishers.
Apply at the lager best saloon, 27½ Broad st. between 1st and 2d, from 2 to 4 o'clock.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A gentleman who has had long experience as a merchant and accountant, and who is at leisure after 3 o'clock P. M. wishes to obtain employment during that portion of the day in Bookkeeping or any other kind of writing Satisfactory references can be given.
Address "Box 827." Richmond P. O.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Immediately, a Professor of Music and a French Teacher.
None but those well qualified need apply.
Liberal salaries given.
Address "Box 180," Danville, Va.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--One or two Rooms, furnished or unfurnished, between 9th and 15th streets for which a liberal rent will be paid.
Address "G. B." Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --Flax Seed.--I will pay the highest cash price for Flax Seed in any quantity.
div3.closer:
W. L. Montague.
Corner Bank and 12th sts. fe 24--4t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A situation as Matron in a hospital, or Housekeeper in a private family.
Address "M. M.," Winder Hospital.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A lady qualified to teach Music wishes to engage a number of Scholars.
Terms moderate.
Apply at the store of Smith & Harwood.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A first rate Washer and Ironer.
Apply at the store of

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A negro Woman, of good character, who is a good Washer and Ironer.
Apply to.

div3.head: For Sale.
div3.p:
--A fine-sized and very likely yellow boy, nineteen or twenty years old. He is very capable, a active waiter, and quite a good cook; would a capital servant for an officer.
Apply at

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A good Cook, Washer and Ironer.
Also, a Dining-Room Servant, and a steady man, accustomed to working in a factory or in the field.
div3.closer:
Mrs. J. Q. James.
Corner 3d and Franklin sts. fe 19--6t*

div3.head: Deserted
div3.p: --$100 reward.--Deserted from Capt. Wm. Lane's Company, 7th Confederate Bangers, Jos P. Bell, a Substitute, between 6 and 12 years of age, five feet two inches high, light hair and has a large scar on the left jaw. The above reward will be given for his delivery to S. C. Lewis. Enfield Halifax county, N. C., or lodged in any jail so that he can be gotten.

div3.head: Morris Artillery.
div3.p: --The following Members of my company now absent without leave are hereby notified that unless they report in person at this camp within seven days from date, they will be considered deserters and treated accordingly:
div3.closer:
William M. Strong.
R. C. M. Page.
Capt. Com'g Mor is Artillery,
D. H. Bill's Division.
Camp near Milford Depot, Feb. 22, 1863. fe 26--2t*

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good, reliable man, to join an infantry company.
None need apply unless over forty five, perfectly sound, and healthy.
Address letters to "E," Dispatch office, between the hours of 10 A. M. and 4 P. M.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--The highest price will be paid for a good Substitute--one over 45 years of age and of good moral character.
Apply to Mr. Z. Meer No. 17 Main street opposite Bodeker's Drug- store, between the hours of 9 and 12 to-day.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in the infantry--company B. 1st Virginia regiment.
For an unexceptionable substitute a liberal price will be paid.
Address "R. S. A." at this office.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--We wish to employ a Substitute.
For a man over forty-five one well recommended — a fair price will be paid.--Apply at once to
div3.closer:
Pollard & Walker.
Cary st. between 12th and 13th. fe 27--1t*

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted, immediately, a Substitute.
One well recommended can obtain a good price and the privilege of choosing his own company.
Apply at Minnis & Co's for three days.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For a reliable man, over 45 and well recommended, a liberal price will be paid.
Apply at once to
div3.closer:
Jas. Williams,
Near Old Market. fe 27--1t*

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--Over 45, who can bring good recommendations as to character, to go in one of the fixed batteries around Richmond.
Apply at No. 29, American Hotel, between the hours of 9 and 12 o'clock.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For a reliable man over 45 years of age and of good character, a fair price will be paid.
Apply immediately at the Picture Store 209 Main st.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in an infantry company.
Apply to

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--To go into an infantry company in General Jackson's corps now near Fredericksburg.
For a reliable man, over 45 years of age, a liberal price will be paid.
Call on W. S. Wright, at Camp Lee, for two days.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted immediately a Substitute.
One well recommended can obtain a good price and the privilege of choosing his own company.
Apply at No. 111 Main street.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid.
Apply to

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid to a sound and reliable man to go as a Substitute in a No. 1 company.
Inquire at Mrs. Barker's, on Grace street, second door above st. Paul's Church.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For the balance of the war. For one over forty-five years of age, with reliable testimonials, a liberal price will be paid.
Apply at the store No. 9. Fourteenth st., between Main and Cary.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--One over 45 years of age, of good character, and sound health.--The highest price will be given.
Apply at No. 151 Main street, Riddle's Ambrotype Gallory.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted, a Substitute to go in a No. 1 artillery company.
None need apply unless he is over 45 years old, sound and healthy, and with a character well endorsed.
For such on one a liberal price will be paid.
A Virginian preferred.
Apply at the office corner of Wall and Franklin sts, to Clopton & Lyne.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--$2,000 will be given for a sound and reliable man over 45 years of age, to go as a substitute in a No. 1 infantry company.
Apply at the Saw Mill, Mayors Oridge.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p: --Over 45 years old. One of sound health and good moral character will be paid a liberal price by calling at
div3.closer:
Davidson & Chockley's,
Cary street, 3 doors below 43rd st,
Richmond, Va. fe 11--ts

div3.head: By Geddin & Apperson Auct's.
div3.p: Commissioner's Sale of Valuable Real Estate in the City of Richmond — as Commissioner appointed by a decree of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond, pronounced on the 7th February, 1863, in the case of Carnell's against Carnell &c, I shall proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, in the order advertised, on Tuesday, the 26th February, 1863, commencing at 3½ o'clock P. M. the following valuable Lots and Tenements, viz:
A lot on the North-side of Catherine, between Monroe and Henry streets 30 by 80 feet, with a double brick kitchen thereon.

list.item:
2d.
A lot, with two brick and stuccoed tenements on Monroe street, near to Brock Avenue, 32 ½ feet by 180 feet.

3d.
A lot, with brick tenement, on the North side of Duval street, 36 by 157 feet, near to St.
Peter street.

4th.
A lot, with frame Dutch-roof tenement, on the North side of Duval street, near the above, 30 by 157 feet.

5th.
A lot, with two frame tenements, near the above on the North side of Duval street, 71 7-12 feet by 157 feet.

6th.
A valuable lot at the corner of Canal and Jefferson streets, 48½ by 120 feet.

7th.
A lot in Turpin's Addition, on French Garden Hill, 60 by 27 fact, being parts of lots Nos 44 and 45.
Terms.--One-fourth cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and title retained till all the purchase money is paid and a conveyance directed by the court; or all cost at the option of the purchaser.
The taxes for this year to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.p: In consequence of the rain the foregoing sale is postponed to Saturday, the 28th of February, 1863, at the same hour.
